Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: They plan to spend the day lounging at home with immediate family.
Story:
I was curled up on the couch in my favorite loose pajamas, hair uncovered, enjoying a rare lazy morning with my parents and little brother. The house was filled with the comforting smells of my mother’s cooking, and I felt at ease, knowing I could relax in my own space. Suddenly, my father called me into the living room. “We need you to lead the family ceremony this year,” he said, his eyes shining with pride. “It’s important to keep our traditions alive, and everyone will be watching.”

My heart skipped. The ceremony meant extended family, neighbors, and even some family friends would be present. Our tradition required the leader to wear a special dress—one that was beautiful but didn’t meet the modesty guidelines I follow as a Muslim. I could already hear my mother’s voice: “It’s just for a few hours, for the family.” But I also felt the weight of my faith, the comfort and conviction I found in dressing modestly, especially in front of others. I sat there, torn, the expectations of being a dutiful daughter and a practicing Muslim pulling me in opposite directions, unsure which part of myself I would have to disappoint.
